title: 112_hr5801
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Unshackling Students to Lead, Excel, Act, Develop, and Serve Act of 2012" or the "U.S. LEADS Act". SEC. 2. FINDINGS.

Congress finds that outstanding student loan debt is expected to reach one trillion dollars this year. In 2008, two-thirds of bachelor's degree graduates had student loan debt, with an average debt of $24,000 in 2010. Only 55.6 percent of 2009 graduates are working in jobs requiring a college degree, while 22.4 percent are unemployed. The median student loan debt for graduates between 2006 and 2010 is $20,000. Additionally, average in-State tuition at public 4-year institutions rose by 8.3 percent between 2010-2011 and 2011-2012 academic years. SEC. 3. Interest-free deferment during periods of national unemployment exceeding 7 percent. FFEL Subsidized Loan Deferment amendment for borrowers aged 21-25 pursuing a degree. The text chunk discusses the conditions for a period of deferment for federal student loans based on national unemployment rates exceeding 7 percent. The curr_chunk discusses the extension of deferment period for federal student loans based on national unemployment rates for individuals aged 21 through 25 exceeding 9 percent. The Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to extend deferment period for federal student loans for borrowers aged 21 to 25 pursuing a specific degree during a consolidation loan. The U.S. Leads Act extends deferment periods for federal student loans for specific circumstances, limiting interest payments to 3 years for one type of deferral and 5 years for another. The U.S. Leads Act extends deferment periods for federal student loans, limiting interest payments to 3 years for one type of deferral and 5 years for another. Additionally, amendments are made to the Higher Education Act of 1965 regarding FFEL Unsubsidized Loan Deferment for borrowers between the ages of 21 and 25. Loans made under this section to the borrower for a period of enrollment pursuing a degree described in section 455(f)(5)(A) with deferred payments will accrue and be paid by the Secretary during the deferment period granted after the enactment of the U.S. Leads Act. Loans under the U.S. Leads Act will accrue and be paid by the Secretary during deferment, not exceeding 3 years for some cases and 5 years for others. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 are also made. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include inserting deferment conditions for specific types of loans, such as Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans, and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 include deferment conditions for Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans for certain borrowers aged 21-25. Amendments to the Higher Education Act of 1965 now allow deferment conditions for Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans for borrowers aged 21-25, who are recent college students pursuing a degree. The Higher Education Act of 1965 allows deferment conditions for Federal Direct Unsubsidized Stafford Loans and Federal Direct Consolidation Loans for borrowers aged 21-25, based on national unemployment rates exceeding 7% or 9% for this age group. The U.S. Leads Act defines a "recent college student" as someone who has received a baccalaureate degree within 48 months prior to the enactment date and has not previously received such a degree.
